parameters.content:
## üìã WORKFLOW OVERVIEW

### üéØ AI CYBERSECURITY BLOG GENERATOR - v1.0

**Purpose:** Automatically generate blog posts from RSS feeds
**Schedule:** Daily at 9:00 AM
**Output:** Google Sheets + Gmail notification

**Owner:** [Your Name/Team]
**Last Updated:** October 21, 2025

#### Quick Stats:
- RSS Source: Bleeping Computer
- Max articles: 3 per run
- Estimated cost: $0.05-0.15 per run

## üì∞ RSS FEED SOURCE

**Current Feed:** Bleeping Computer
**URL:** https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/feed/

### ‚öôÔ∏è Settings:
- Fetches last 24 hours of articles
- Retry: 3 attempts (feed might be temporarily down)

### üîÑ To change feed:
Update RSS Read node URL parameter

üìù Other feeds available in project docs

## üîç CONTENT FILTERING

**Looking for:** AI + Cybersecurity articles

### Keywords (title OR description):
- "AI" / "artificial intelligence"
- "machine learning" / "ML"
- "neural network"
- "deep learning"
- "LLM" / "large language model"

### üí° TIP:
- Too few results? Reduce keywords
- Too many? Add more specific terms

üìä **Expected:** 1-5 matching articles per day

## ‚ö†Ô∏è COST CONTROL

**Current Limit:** 3 articles maximum

### Why? Prevents:
- Excessive AI API costs
- Long execution times
- Rate limit issues

### üí∞ Estimated cost per run:
$0.05-0.15 (based on 3 articles √ó AI API pricing)

### üîÑ To process more:
Increase limit in node settings

## üìÑ ARTICLE CONTENT FETCHING

### Process:
1. HTTP Request fetches full webpage
2. HTML Extract pulls main article text
3. Removes ads, navigation, footers

### ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Issues:
- **Paywall sites:** Will get partial content
- **Dynamic sites:** May need different extraction
- **Rate limiting:** 30sec timeout + 3 retries

### üîß If extraction fails:
Check HTML selectors

## ü§ñ AI BLOG POST GENERATION

**Model:** OpenAI GPT-4 / Claude / etc.
**Target Length:** 500-800 words

### Prompt Strategy:
- Analyze source article
- Focus on AI + cybersecurity intersection
- Include practical implications
- Add source attribution

### ‚öôÔ∏è Settings:
- **Max tokens:** 1500 (controls cost)
- **Temperature:** 0.7 (balance creativity/accuracy)
- **Retry:** 2 attempts

üí° **To adjust tone:** Modify prompt in node settings

parameters.text:
=You are an expert cybersecurity blogger who specializes in AI applications in security.

Analyze the following article and write a comprehensive blog post (500-800 words) that:
1. Summarizes the key points of the article
2. Explains the implications for AI and cybersecurity
3. Discusses practical applications or concerns
4. Provides valuable insights for security professionals
5. Includes a compelling title

Article Title: {{ $('RSS Feed Read').item.json.title }}
Article URL: {{ $('RSS Feed Read').item.json.link }}
Article Content: {{ $json.content }}

Write the blog post in a professional yet accessible tone. Focus on actionable insights and real-world implications.

Format your response as:

TITLE: [Your catchy blog title]

[Your blog post content]

SOURCE: {{ $('RSS Feed Read').item.json.title }} - {{ $('RSS Feed Read').item.json.link }}

parameters.content:
## üíæ GOOGLE SHEETS OUTPUT

**Sheet Name:** "AI Security Blogs"
**Sheet ID:** [paste actual ID here]

### Columns:
- **A:** Date (auto-generated)
- **B:** Source Article Title
- **C:** Source URL
- **D:** Generated Blog Post
- **E:** Status (Success/Failed)
- **F:** Error Message (if any)

üîë **Permissions:** Ensure n8n has edit access
üìä **View sheet:** [paste Google Sheets URL here]

## üìß SUCCESS EMAIL

**Recipient:** [your-email@domain.com]

### ‚úÖ Sent when:
Blog posts generated successfully

### Contains:
- Number of articles processed
- Link to Google Sheets
- Brief summary

üîá **To reduce noise:** Update recipient or add filters

parameters.subject: ‚úÖ Daily AI Security Blog Generated

parameters.content:
## üìß FAILURE EMAIL

**Recipient:** [your-email@domain.com]

### ‚ùå Sent when:
Workflow encounters errors

### Contains:
- Error details
- Which step failed
- Troubleshooting suggestions

üîî **This helps you fix issues quickly**

parameters.subject: ‚ùå Daily AI Security Blog Failed
parameters.message:
=‚ùå ERROR: AI Security Blog Generation Failed

üìä Summary:
- Total articles attempted: {{ $json.totalCount }}
- Successful generations: {{ $json.successCount }}
- Failed generations: {{ $json.failCount }}

‚ö†Ô∏è All generations failed. Please check:
- RSS feed availability
- AI API credentials and rate limits
- Google Sheets permissions
- Network connectivity

üîß View execution logs in n8n for detailed error information.

üìÖ Timestamp: {{ $json.timestamp }}

---
AI Cybersecurity Blog Generator v1.0

parameters.content:
## üîß TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE

### Problem: No articles generated
‚Üí Check if RSS feed is down
‚Üí Relax filter keywords
‚Üí Check execution log for errors

### Problem: Poor quality blog posts
‚Üí Adjust AI prompt in Agent node
‚Üí Increase max tokens
‚Üí Try different AI model

### Problem: Workflow not running
‚Üí Verify schedule trigger is active
‚Üí Check workflow activation toggle (top right)

### Problem: Google Sheets not updating
‚Üí Verify credentials are still valid
‚Üí Check sheet permissions

üìö **Need help?** Check n8n docs or contact support

## ‚ö†Ô∏è ERROR HANDLING STRATEGY

### All critical nodes set to:
- **Continue On Fail** = true
- Retries configured appropriately

### Error Paths:
‚ùå RSS Feed fails ‚Üí Error email sent
‚ùå No articles match ‚Üí Info email (not error)
‚ùå HTTP fetch fails ‚Üí Logged to sheet + email
‚ùå AI generation fails ‚Üí Logged + email

### Retry Strategy:
- **Network calls:** 3 retries, 30-60sec wait
- **API calls:** 2 retries, 60sec wait
- **Google Sheets:** 2 retries, 10sec wait

**This ensures you're always notified!**

## üß™ MANUAL TESTING

**Click "Test Workflow" button to test without waiting for schedule**

### Testing Checklist:
‚ñ° RSS feed returns articles
‚ñ° Filter finds relevant content
‚ñ° Articles are fetched successfully
‚ñ° AI generates readable blog posts
‚ñ° Google Sheets updates correctly
‚ñ° Gmail notification sent

üí° **Always test in "Test Workflow" mode first!**

### üîÑ After testing successfully:
1. Click "Save" button
2. Toggle "Active" switch to enable schedule

## üìå QUICK REFERENCE

### üîß Configuration:
- **RSS:** Bleeping Computer
- **Schedule:** Daily 9AM
- **Limit:** 3 articles max
- **Email:** [your@email.com]
- **Cost/run:** ~$0.10

### üîó Important Links:
- **Google Sheet:** [paste URL]
- **RSS Feed:** bleepingcomputer.com/feed
- **n8n Docs:** docs.n8n.io

üìù **Last Updated:** Oct 21, 2025
üë§ **Owner:** [Your Name]

parameters.text:
=Classify if this article is about BOTH AI and cybersecurity.
CRITERIA:
- Must involve AI/ML tools, systems, or models
- Must relate to security, attacks, or defenses
- AI can be the subject (AI tool vulnerabilities) OR method (AI for attack/defense)
RESPOND with either: 
{"relevant": true} or {"relevant": false}
EXAMPLES:
Title: "SharePoint ToolShell attacks target organizations"
{"relevant": false}
Reason: SharePoint isn't an AI tool

Title: "Cursor, Windsurf IDEs have 94+ Chromium vulnerabilities"
{"relevant": true}
Reason: Cursor/Windsurf are AI code editors with security flaws

Title: "AI model detects zero-day exploits with 95% accuracy"
{"relevant": true}
Reason: AI used for security defense

Title: "Hackers breach networks using phishing emails"
{"relevant": false}
Reason: No AI involvement

Title: "ChatGPT jailbreak bypasses content filters"
{"relevant": true}
Reason: AI system security vulnerability

just output the result of the analysis as {"relevant": ...}
NOW CLASSIFY: 
Title: {{ $json.title }}
Description: {{ $json.contentSnippet }}"

Cursor, Windsurf IDEs riddled with 94+ n-day Chromium vulnerabilities

By
Bill Toulas
  • October 21, 2025
  • 03:00 PM
  • 1

The latest releases of Cursor and Windsurf integrated development environments are vulnerable to more than 94 known and patched security issues in the Chromium browser and the V8 JavaScript engine.

An estimated 1.8 million developers, the userbase for the two IDEs, are exposed to the risks.

Ox Security researchers explain that both development environments are built on old software that includes outdated versions of the open-source Chromium browser and Google's V8 engine.

They say that Cursor and Windsurf rely on old versions of VS Code that include old releases of the Electron framework for building cross-platform apps using web technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript).

"Since Electron embeds Chromium and V8, this means the IDEs rely on outdated Chromium and V8 engines, exposing them to vulnerabilities that have already been patched in newer versions," the researchers say in a report shared with BleepingComputer.

The researchers say that Cursor and Windsurf are vulnerable to at least 94 vulnerabilities present in the Chromium builds they use.

Despite the security issue being disclosed responsibly since October 12, the risks are still present as Cursor considered the report "out of scope" and Windsurf did not respond.

Chrome risks on the IDE

Cursor and Windsurf are AI-powered code editors forked from Visual Studio Code. They integrate large-language models (LLMs) to help developers write software more easily and quickly.

They are distributed as Electron apps, meaning an application runtime that packages a specific Chromium build for rendering web content, and includes the browser's V8 JavaScript engine in the binary.

The specific Electron release pins a Chromium + V8 version, and if the vendor doesn't upgrade it, flaws fixed in every subsequent release become exploitable risks in the IDE.

Ox Security demonstrated that it is possible to exploit the Maglev JIT integer overflow described in CVE-2025-7656 through a deeplink, which executes Cursor and injects a prompt instructing its browser to visit a remote URL hosting an exploit payload.

The remote page serves JavaScript that triggers CVE-2025-7656 exploitation, causing denial of service by crashing the renderer.

Nir Zadok and Moshe Siman Tov Bustan of Ox Security demonstrated their findings by targeting Cursor IDE with an exploit for CVE-2025-7656, an integer overflow vulnerability in Google Chrome's V8 engine fixed on July 15.

The proof-of-concept exploit caused Cursor to enter a denial-of-service condition (crash), as shown in the video below:

However, Ox Security notes that arbitrary code execution is also possible in real-world attacks.

An adversary would have multiple options to trigger the vulnerability. The researchers say that an attacker could use a malicious extension to trigger the exploit or inject the exploit code into documentation and tutorials.

Hackers could also rely on classic phishing attacks or leverage poisoned repositories by planting malicious code in README files that are previewed in the IDE.

Ox Security notes that the exploit does not work on the latest VS Code, which is regularly updated and addresses all known bugs.

Upon receiving the proof-of-concept exploit, Cursor dismissed the report by saying that self-inflicted DoS is out of scope.

But the researchers noted that this stance ignores the more severe exploitation potential of the flaw, including memory-corruption primitives, or even the broader set of unpatched CVEs in the Electron apps used.

"Since their last Chromium update on 2025-03-21 for version 0.47.9 since Chromium 132.0.6834.210 was out, at least 94 known CVEs have been published. We've weaponized just one. The attack surface is massive," explains Ox Security.

BleepingComputer has contacted both Cursor and Windsurf asking for a comment on Ox Security's report, but we have not heard back by publication time.

Picus Blue Report 2025 is Here: 2X increase in password cracking

46% of environments had passwords cracked, nearly doubling from 25% last year.

Get the Picus Blue Report 2025 now for a comprehensive look at more findings on prevention, detection, and data exfiltration trends.

Bill Toulas is a tech writer and infosec news reporter with over a decade of experience working on various online publications, covering open-source, Linux, malware, data breach incidents, and hacks.

Overview of the attack Source: Ox Security Ox Security notes that the exploit does not work on the latest VS Code, which is regularly updated and addresses all known bugs. Upon receiving the proof-of-concept exploit, Cursor dismissed the report by saying that self-inflicted DoS is out of scope. But the researchers noted that this stance ignores the more severe exploitation potential of the flaw, including memory-corruption primitives, or even the broader set of unpatched CVEs in the Electron apps used. "Since their last Chromium update on 2025-03-21 for version 0.47.9 since Chromium 132.0.6834.210 was out, at least 94 known CVEs have been published. We've weaponized just one. The attack surface is massive," explains Ox Security. BleepingComputer has contacted both Cursor and Windsurf asking for a comment on Ox Security's report, but we have not heard back by publication time. Picus Blue Report 2025 is Here: 2X increase in password cracking 46% of environments had passwords cracked, nearly doubling from 25% last year. Get the Picus Blue Report 2025 now for a comprehensive look at more findings on prevention, detection, and data exfiltration trends. json.output:
TITLE: **AI-Powered IDEs: The Hidden Cost of Speed? How 94+ Chromium Vulnerabilities Threaten Developer Security**

The rapid adoption of AI-driven development tools is transforming how we code, promising unprecedented productivity. However, a critical security assessment by Ox Security reveals a dangerous underbelly: popular AI-powered IDEs Cursor and Windsurf are built on outdated, vulnerable foundations, exposing an estimated 1.8 million developers to significant risk.

**Key Findings from the Report:**  
1.  **94+ N-Day Vulnerabilities:** Both Cursor and Windsurf IDEs are forked from older versions of VS Code, embedding outdated builds of Chromium (the open-source core of Chrome) and Google‚Äôs V8 JavaScript engine. This legacy code includes at least **94 known, unpatched vulnerabilities** (n-days) fixed in current Chromium releases but unaddressed in these IDEs.  
2.  **Electron Framework Culprit:** The IDEs use an obsolete version of the Electron framework, which locks in specific, dated Chromium/V8 builds. Vendors failing to update Electron inherit all subsequent patched flaws.  
3.  **Exploit Demonstration:** Researchers weaponized **CVE-2025-7656** (a high-severity V8 integer overflow patched months ago) to crash the IDE via a malicious deep link. Evidence suggests *arbitrary code execution* (RCE) is feasible in real attacks.  
4.  **Attack Vectors Abound:** Malicious extensions, compromised documentation/tutorials, poisoned repo README files (previewed in the IDE), or phishing links could trigger exploits.  
5.  **Vendor Inaction:** Cursor dismissed the risk as "out of scope" (focusing only on self-DoS), while Windsurf didn‚Äôt respond. Contrastly, current VS Code remains secure via regular updates.  

**Implications for AI and Cybersecurity:**  
This isn't just about patching bugs‚Äîit‚Äôs about the security posture of tools enabling tomorrow‚Äôs software:  
- **AI Acceleration vs. Security Debt:** AI features (like integrated LLMs) draw developers, but vendors may prioritize speed *over* dependency hygiene, turning IDEs into attack surfaces.  
- **Supply Chain Risks Amplified:** Vulnerable dev tools compromise the integrity and security of *all code produced* within them, enabling software supply chain attacks.  
- **N-Day Threats ‚â† Low Risk:** "Patched" flaws become critical when embedded in essential tools with stagnant dependencies. Attackers actively target such outdated components.  

**Practical Concerns and Applications:**  
1.  **Expanded Attack Surface:** Developers' IDEs now handle network requests, render web content, and parse untrusted data (e.g., repo docs). Compromising the IDE grants attackers persistent access to dev environments and potentially corporate networks.  
2.  **AI as an Attack Vector?** AI assistants accepting prompts via deep links (as exploited by Ox) could inadvertently execute malicious instructions.  
3.  **The Vendor Responsibility Gap:** Cursor‚Äôs dismissal highlights a dangerous mentality‚Äîdownplaying "self-inflicted" risks ignores weaponization potential.  

**Actionable Insights for Security Professionals:**  
1.  **Inventory & Assess:** Identify if Cursor, Windsurf, or other Electron-based tools are in your dev ecosystem. Scrutinize dependency trees for outdated Chromium/V8.  
2.  **Pressure Vendors:** Demand transparency on dependency update cycles. Switch to tools (like VS Code) with proven patch discipline if vendors are unresponsive.  
3.  **Segment Developer Environments:** Treat developer workstations as high-risk assets. Enforce network segmentation, strict execution policies, and monitor IDE processes.  
4.  **Scan for Malicious Artifacts:** Implement controls to detect poisoned docs, extensions, or scripts targeting the IDE's renderer process.  
5.  **Raise Developer Awareness:** Train teams on risks of interacting with untrusted content/repos *within* the IDE, and safe extension practices.  

### The Bottom Line
While AI-powered tools enhance developer velocity, they must not become the weakest link in your security chain. The Cursor/Windsurf incident underscores a critical lesson: **Innovation cannot come at the cost of foundational security hygiene.** Security teams must extend scrutiny beyond production code to the *tools building it*‚Äîbecause when developers‚Äô arsenals are compromised, the battlefield is already lost.  

Proactively managing third-party dependencies in development tools isn't optional; it's the bedrock of modern DevSecOps. As AI integrates deeper into coding, ensuring these platforms themselves are fortified is the next frontier in cybersecurity defense.  

**SOURCE:** [Cursor, Windsurf IDEs riddled with 94+ n-day Chromium vulnerabilities](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/cursor-windsurf-ides-riddled-with-94-plus-n-day-chromium-vulnerabilities/)
